MR. SNEDAKER: This is not only the theme of the U.S. exhibit but fundamental¬
ly the theme of Japan, the United States and all the Free
World—for when there is plenty there is peace.
Realization of the fact that improved world living standards
Can be the greatest single deterrent to war, caused the
United States, at the end of World II, to embark on an
unprecedented program to help the free nations rehabilitate
themselves, expand their economies and raise their standards
of living.
Basically living standards are raised by producing more of
the products and services of industry, business and agriculture
and making these available to the consumer at prices he can
afford. The process, wisely carried out, results in more
employment, higher wages, more domestic consumption and more
products available for export at competitive prices.
Maximum success requires at least 3 basic ingredients:
1. Research pointing to greater efficiency and improved
techniques.
2. Capital to effect the improvements.
3. Vigorous, hard-working, skilled, educated, imaginative
people to make the most of the opportunities for more
efficient production and more effective sales and distribution
techniques.
The United States, currently spending some $4-billion annually
on research, has a wealth of technical know-how. America
also has capital.
Japan has the hard-working, educated people but has lacked
the research and capital required for success in rapidly
improving living standards.
